reviewText:
This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.
Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey Remastered is an addictive spelling game - this remastered edition came about quite quick, given that the original release was only brought out on Steam a little under a year ago in November 2014. This remastered version hit the store front in August of 2015.

The main gameplay element in Letter Quest is spelling words in order to deal damage to your foes. You play in a side scrolling dungeon crawl type environment, and you have to defeat a number of enemies in order to reach the treasure at the end of the dungeon.  You have fifteen letters each round which are randomly selected for you and you just need to spell out a word, each of the letters have their own special rarity, so if you stick some Ws and Xs in your words, they will end up doing more damage compared to sticking to simple words like Door" or something
date: very similar to the likes of the rules in Scrabble or Words with Friends.  Some of the monsters have special abilities
voteText: one enemy might not take any damage from any words which contain the letter E
votesTotal: or sometimes twenty times more damage from words containing other letters. Some enemies may use a special ability and make your letters also have a debuff on
votesFunny: such as rendering them useless and dealing zero damage from then
column17: or stopping you from using them all together. All of these combined with the other strengths and weaknesses of the monsters can really lead to some interesting runs.\n\nEach run through a dungeon you are also collecting gems from defeating the enemies
column18: completing small quests and looting the jewels at the end of the dungeon. You can in turn use these gems to upgrade your character with health points
column20: and dodge chance increases and many more. This allows you to build your character however you want. Along with a huge selection of weapons to choose from as you unlock more from either progressing in the story mode
column21: completing quests and challenges. There is so much to unlock in Letter Quest that you can be farming gems for hours and still not have it all unlocked.  Each stage has four levels of difficulty; completing each stage grants a star
column22: and rewards you with more gems. You can also replay previously completed dungeons if you want to farm more gems too.\n\nLetter Quest has a really nice looking aesthetic too; the graphics are very simple 2D
column23: but the games own unique style really shines through. The UI is really nicely designed too; obviously you are going to be spending a lot of your time looking at the letters at your disposal
column24: so it's nice that the game also includes a number of different skins for the letter's style
column25: letting you change it up once you get bored of one style.\n\nEven though the game classes the main mode of the game to be "story mode"
column26: there isn't really any story at all. There is absolutely no back story
column27: or any dialog in the game
column29: I wasn't all that bothered about the lack of a plot either.\n\nI found Letter Quest to be a fairly difficult game; but as you get playing
column30: you get more and more used to it
column31: practice makes perfect. If you are good at games such as Scrabble
column32: or you know plenty of fancy big words
column33: you'll excel in this game. The RPG element is not exactly difficult to master
column34: you can create any sort of character build that takes your fancy
column35: I focused mainly on health regeneration because my fights tended to last a bit longer due to only being able to get six letter words most of the time - there are builds which focuses on farming gems
column37: or just simply not taking any damage at all.\n\nCompleting Letter Quest with the majority of the stages being completed on all four difficulties
column38: took me just over twelve hours to finish. I felt that it was a really good length
column39: and given the amount of replay ability
column40: I can see Letter Quest easily hitting the fifteen hour mark if you fancy taking on the endless mode.\n\nLetter Quest can be played entirely with a keyboard
column41: since you are typing out the words. You can also play the entire game without touching the keyboard and purely using the mouse too. I also spent a lot of time using my Steam controller on this game
column42: and that works perfectly with the trackpads
column43: there are a few community made binding sets which all work well too; so if you have a steam controller
column44: give it ago with Letter Quest.\n\nI fully enjoyable myself whilst playing Letter Quest - this is a casual game but will completely suck you in and get your addicted straight away. I and my partner played this game together for the most part
column45: and minutes soon turned into hours and hours soon turned into long sessions ploughing through the levels together. It's a game which you can quite easily keep installed on your machine and jump into every now and again too. There is very little to learn in terms of the gameplay as it purely uses your own spelling knowledge. Letter Quest's regular price is ¬£5
column47: which in itself is an absolute bargain for the amount of content on offer
column48: and the quality of it - so if you can get it any less than that
column49:
pick it up in a heartbeat as you won't find a better word based game on Steam.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful
column50: please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/\n\nhttp://store.steampowered.com/app/373970"

reviewText:
Letter Quest is a casual word game with some RPG elements added to it. It boasts 40 different levels each providing 4 different challenges for the player (giving you a grand total of 160 challenges). If that's not enough for you, the expert mode unlocks once you've completed the game on the regular one. The RPG elements allows you to customize your character and allow for a natural progression since the challenges become tougher as the game progresses.

The remastered edition has improved animations and the new endless mode for a different challenge that improves replayability.

Not being a native English speaker, I consider the game the provide a decent challenge while not pushing me away. It actually has that just one more" quality that will have you engulf many hours in it without really noticing. A real word aficionado might find the regular mode on the easy side but will certainly enjoy the more challenging expert mode. It took me about 10 hours to complete the main quest and roughly 75% of the overall challenges. Depending on your level of vocabulary
date: you can probably complete the whole thing (including achievements) on normal in 10 to 15 hours.\n\nOverall a really enjoyable game that's easy to pick up and play for a quick session or to really dive into for hours at a time. I suggest you give the demo a try even if you're not usually a fan of word games."
helpfulPercent: 25 of 26 people (96%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was a big fan of the original version of Letter Quest, and the remastered version continues to be one of my favourite pick up and play games. The game itself will appeal to anyone who enjoys Scrabble, Puzzle Quest, or slaughtering dangerous monsters through the power of their vocabulary.

Touch screen: This is one of the best games available on Steam for anyone who owns a windows tablet, as it controls absolutely perfectly through touch. It's honestly flawless: not once did I feel hampered, annoyed, or even mildly inconvenienced using the UI through touch. If you own a windows tablet, you should own this game. (For info's sake I play on a Surface Pro 1.)

Also, the dev is a pretty nice guy. Despite this being a niche game and not exactly making the creator wealthy, he went out of his way to ensure that all previous purchasers of Letter Quest recieved the remastered version free of charge. I appreciate that.

Oh yes, works just great in both Windows 8 and Windows 10. No crashes, runs great.
voteText: 22 of 24 people (92%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a very fun little typing puzzle fighter, (I guess thats what we will call it :) ). I love the style of this game, its like a dungeon crawler x puzzle typing game.  The animation is cute the challenges make the game fun, great scaling on the star difficulties.  The quests add an element of challenge as well trying to complete certain parameters for extra gems to buy things from the shopkeep such as stat boosts and BACON!! (used in place of health potion).

There isnt really too much on the negative side. If you were wondering about keyboard functionality the keyboard is responsive no problems there.  I suppose I have had a few bad jumbles of letters in a row but they give you a shuffle button to use it counts as your turn but at least you arent stuck with bad letters turn after turn trying to make words out of them.

All of that said I would recommend this to people I think it could be fun for anyone, maybe moreso for those who enjoy typing or puzzle type games. I would load this on my surface or tablet and take it with me when traveling I feel this would be perfect for that :)
voteText: 21 of 23 people (91%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Definitely recommended!

It's fun, it's cute, it joggs the brain. Whether you're super brain or fuzzy old me, it's playable by everyone who can spell English words.

You play as Grimm, a little reaper who is on a quest to get pizza. You venture through various locations where you have to beat up monsters by spelling words from 15 available random letters.

Along the way, you free shopkeepers who sell you stuff for the gems you earn; upgrades, special abilities, books, potions, weapons. There's even two more characters to unlock that you can play with, with different stats (but all upgrades, special abilities, and stuff transfer)

The monsters vary too, some have special conditions to take damage at all, or to take double, or even quadruple damage. Some throw stuff at your letters that makes them dangerous, unavailable, or adding no points to a word. Sometimes some letters aren't available, sometimes you're limited in the amount of words or letters you may use. and more. Always something new and different!

At every stage (location) you have a plain normal level, one with limited time, one with varied special conditions, and one extra tough one. If I'm not mistaken, there are 40 stages. Plus of course the new endless mode (haven't tried that yet).

And for those like me who don't like timers, just pause the game by clicking help (better than making a screenshot and pausing the game). I like it a lot that the game does not force the timed rounds at all cost.

Also, I got this for free because I own the previous version. That's a very neat move by the developer. He's also very responsive and friendly.

With the new engine opening new developement options, I still hope he'll add a free play mode/level with picked/random monsters, after the final boss has been beaten.

But in any case, as it is it's a fun, charming game. Even losing a level makes me smile with the cute animation of little Grimm lying there with x'ed eyes. Or the Dust bunny whacking me over the head with the duster.

reviewText:
So yeah, this is a game you could pretty much play endlessly if you were so inclined, and it's really a ton of fun. Part Scrabble, part 2D Crawler. Really just a well made game. I will say however that it doesnt recognize a fair amount of words, but yet somehow all the racist and hate words made it into the game. Not sure why. They probably thought it would be funny if you kind of had to use them while in battle.

Anyway, really fun, and with the ultimate reward at the end. I enjoyed it and can see myself playing it despite having finished the campaign, to get the rest of the unlocks and such.

9 words vaulting you onto a higher plane of fictitious consciousness out of 10 possible.

reviewText:
Addictive little typing game with adorable artstyle.
I really enjoy playing this, you have 25 letters on the board that are selected randomly and you need to create letters to defeat enemies that stand in your way on your quest for... pizza? I think I missed that part of the plot.
Its addictive, cute and enjoyable if you have nothing else to do and just want to spend some time, or just want to practice some English!
The game intoduced you to the simple RPG elements, like levelling up your weapons and getting upgrades that can help you in defeating strong enemies.
Definitely recommend to anyone who likes scrabble or any similar games.

reviewText:
Fantastic little word game, which can be described as a scrabble-meets-RPG (or to be more precise: monster mashing in a fantasy setting with basic cRPG elements, if you like).

As in original scrabble, you are building words from letter tiles, but instead of accumulating points, you are using them to defeat your opponents. There is loot, potions, various unlockables, character development and... yes, there are quests! (scrabble-like, mainly about building specific number of words meeting specific criteria).

The game has a high replay value (it's a word game, after all), and after beating Story Mode (there is little story about it, actually - rather a sequence of challenges), there is so-called Endless Mode"
hoursPlayed: and the question - how long can you survive?\n\nProduction value is high as well - it's a casual game
voteText: but a very polished one. Cartoonish presentation adds a lot of charm - it's cute
helpfulPercent: colorful and clean. Ingame music is diverse and works really well; it didn't force me to turn it off
votesHelpful: and I was playing for hours.\n\nI would recommend this
votesTotal: if you find tradidional word games boring
votesFunny: but like the idea of word-building game with defined goals and/or light cRPG flavor. Well
column16:
it's still worth trying.

Pros:

+ high replay value with Story Mode and Endless Mode
+ graphics and decent music (and high production value overall)
+ achievements very well balanced - manageable
column17:
but giving you a nice feeling of progession.

Cons:

None. This is pretty much perfect for what it is."

reviewText:
Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey Remastered
Note: Lack of hours gameplay - I've played the first game on PC and on other devices. This is a remastered version of the original with differences stated below.


Overview: Essentially as described, more of the same word finding with an RPG twist.

Graphics: Simple, cutesy, smooth and clean for those running at higher resolutions.

Music: New music is nice, however, you can switch to the original should you wish.

Gameplay: Much the same, though with a endless mode should you wish and a wealth of achievements (60 at present).

Overall: A good value game which should certainly entertain both those who enjoy words and those seeking achievements

reviewText:
Boggle meets a sideways scrolling cartoony dungeon crawler? With an upgrade tree & powerups? And it's good? Oh, yes.

Enter a dungeon, meet an enemy. Make a word, do damage based on word quality. Use power-ups. Beat enemy. Earn coins. Spend coins to upgrade skills/books/weapon. Beat more enemies. Beat time trials & big bosses, and fulfill quests. Rinse. Repeat.

This is top notch fun, if you're a word-game fan. Just the right amount of presentation to not get in the way & be super smooth. Just enough upgrades & coins & quests to get that 'one more game' urge.

Love it.

reviewText:
Letter Quest is a game where you fight monsters by combining letters to form words. Attack damage is based on word length and rarity of the letters.

Positives
+ The game is well explained and easy to understand, so you can start playing straight away.
+ The difficulty is increased in ways that logically fit the theme.
+ You can replay any level (with new letters) which is fun to do and also provides more currency to buy stuff.
+ The developer is active on the forums and is adding missing words.
+ Loads of upgrades and items to buy, to match different play styles and levels.
+ The remastered version was free for owners of the original.
+ Each level has variations, to keep things fresh and increase difficulty.
+ Special enemies have additional word requirements, to increase the challenge.
+ Loads of extra challenges and achievements (i.e. use three words that don't have vowels).
+ Includes definitions of words.
+ A campaign mode with levels and an endless mode, if you want to see how far you can get.
+ Tons of replayability. Every level is procedural and the campaign can be replayed on expert mode.
+ Options: Can change key bindings and resolution. Fullscreen on/off. Different volume scales for effects and music.
+ Makes you feel a bit smarter!

Negatives
- Some of the quests go against the idea of the game. For example: Take 200 damage". This isn't something to be proud of achieving and it doesn't add any challenge to the game. It just rewards failure.
- A minor design issue occurs when using the keyboard on a level with the same letter on the board twice
date: but with different attributes (i.e. one is normal and one is poisoned). There doesn't appear to be a way to specify the desired letter
hoursPlayed: this issue only matters on timed levels and only in that situation
voteText: so isn't a big deal.\n- Some profanity does not count as valid words. So it's disappointing to come up with a word and then the game doesn't allow it. At this point the player has already typed the word
helpfulPercent:
so I can't see the benefit of not allowing it. This should at least be optional.

Ideas
# It would be nice to get a bonus
votesHelpful:
if a timed level was completed significantly under the time.
# Bit surprised that there's no quest/achievement for getting really long words (10+).
# Long word definitions get cut-off (e.g. Islam). This could be solved by showing the text in a tooltip.

Overall this is an well-designed and entertaining game. All of the negatives are minor and are far outweighed by the positives. Definitely recommended."

reviewText:
First off, I would just like to say thank you to the developers for their kindness to those who had purchased the previous game by offering this version for free. It was very kind :3

I've only reached the forest so far, it's upgraded and cleaned up quite a bit from what the original used to be. The unity player touch is very nice. The music is well done and the achievements have been expanded. My only real complaint about this game is only that the vocabulary list was never expanded apon. Lots of modern day nouns and verbs are missing and I had hoped that famous locations would also have been included but are not (Ex: Rome, Greece, etc).

Other then that the game is a nice, peaceful time waster with some brainstorming required, especially on the time trial modes. I haven't messed with Endless yet, but will as soon as I play the story out.

Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey is a fun little word game where the object of the game is to defeat monsters by creating words. The game in itself is sort of like a mobile game, but its something that I would play when I'm bored and only have a little time to play games. Letter Quest is not extremely easy and has semi RPG elements in it such as upgrades and increases in certain things that make going on easier. Another thing is that the monsters can make the tiles have different negative effects which really affects your damage sometimes. Some of the challenge monsters or bosses even have certain conditions that you have to fullfill to beat them, such as words with double letters do quadruple damage" and that kind of stuff. A lot of Letter Quest actaully took me a lot of tries to beat and there are some levels where I haven't completed all challenges yet and probably won't ever. Overall
date: fun little game but don't buy it for full price unless you really like games like this.\n\nRating: 7.7/10"

reviewText: Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey was a breath of fresh air in a video game world that is over saturated with zombie and survival games. My girlfriend and i had a great time playing together, there isn't any multiplayer per-se but it's one of those games where you can just sit beside a friend and spout off any words that come into your head. If i were to compare this game to another to give you a general idea of what you're in store for would be, Boggle, that's right, the classic game night word game Boggle wrapped in an RPG. If you were hesitant in purchasing this for any reason i would say give it a shot, It's a ton of fun  for just under 9 bucks it's a steal. Letter Quest even has Steam Trading Cards, need i say more?

reviewText: Honestly, a really amazingly cute, casual and fun game!\nWould recommend for people who aren't much into AAA titles, or who just wanna chill on a not-so-easy-yet-relaxing game~\nGreat work people <3 !

I enjoyed this game before it was ever on Steam, and that's not something that happens often these days. Now the Remastered version is giving me an excuse to play it all over again.\n\nIf you like word games, you probably don't need to know much more than that the letter distribution is good and the mechanics are sound. If you need a little more to be sold on it, there is character progression with power-ups and abilities that you can unlock and buy, and the combat mechanic feels balanced and fun. The enemies have varied attacks, including tainting the tiles with such hurdles as poison or spikes (which deal damage to you when you use them) or even turning them to stone (which you can't use). There is room for strategy (do I use that S to make CASTLE now, or save it for later, when I can use it at the end of the word and get a bonus from my pluralize" spell?)
date: the achievements are motivating (all doable with a little patience)
recommended: and there are in-game quests to keep you going and shake things up when it starts to feel repetitive.\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
Basically a rip-off of Bookworm Adventures but with higher-res graphics.  Nothing wrong with that, always room for more Word puzzle games in my view!  Just doesn't do anything different though, and lacks the charm (IMHO) of Bookworm - even the cheesy 'jokes' are worse...

Worth it when on sale at a big discount; otherwise try the various Bookworm games or (my current fave) Alphabetty Saga which is free on Android and Facebook and more fun, again only my opinion: YMMV.

Cheers!

Edit:  Just played Bookworm Adventures 2 to check and yes, it definitely is more fun than this, can't put my finger on exactly why... worth trying both as they're relatively cheap.

reviewText: Good idea, but it gets repetitive fast and forces you to have to buy certain upgrades to progress. So there really isn't much of a choice in how you play the game, even though there are various upgrades.\n\nIt would have been better if there was more upgrades and that they were more powerful, so that you could customize how you played the game. reviewText:
I'm not sure what was the point of switching to Unity for this game. The Flash platform can be conveniently replaced with the OpenFL + Haxe environment, would have saved the author a lot of time. Anyway, I'll take this as a training exercise for future Unity games, right?

The Remastered version adds a new optional soundtrack, which is pretty good but a far cry from the magnificence of the original's soundtrack. Seriously, when you have talent like this, you credit them, instead of pushing them to the side. It's still easily the best indie soundtrack I've heard since the days of Shatter and VVVVV.

There's also the endless mode. I tried it once, and found it stressful. I play LQ for relaxation, so it's a no-go for me. Maybe it's possible to save between battles and not have to do it all in a single session, I'm not sure. I'll have to play it again in the future though, since I'd like to 100% this game's achievements for once. I got my 40th star in expert mode a couple of days after the game's release, must have been one of the first. I greatly enjoyed the difficulty curve; perhaps because I'd already finished it twice in normal mode.

LQ, whether in normal or remastered mode, is more polished than the earlier (and unrelated) 'Bookworm' games, which LQ shamelessly borrowed from. Then again, it's fair game when you're taking from a company (PopCap) that made its fortune on Bejeweled, which was itself heavily inspired by a lesser known game...

Do whatever you want, but play this game. Unless of course you don't want to. In which case, why are you even reading this review? You should get some help.

reviewText: Letter Quest is basically Scrabble with RPG elements such as quests, upgrades and monsters! Now the concept itself was what enticed me to buy this game in the first place, but when you actually get into the game you start to realise that the game becomes rather dull and repetitive. The quests are relatively easy to complete, but the amount of crystals" (the in-game currency) you get per quests are sort of miniscule compared to the amount that you need to even buy one upgrade when you get to higher levels. Each level also gets exponentially more difficult so unless you are a Scrabble genius or have been buying A LOT of upgrades
date: you wouldn't be able to pass the level
recommended: which just sort of turns this game into a grind hell.\n\nAlthough in saying that
hoursPlayed: I haven't explored the game enough to know if there is some sort of mind-blowing story or a very rewarding experience waiting for me at the end. I'll update this review when I have progressed further into the game
voteText: though for now I can't really give this game my recommendation for the torturous first few hours I am experiencing."

reviewText:
Super-duper-awesome word game for young and old gamers!
I used to play the original letter quest alot here on Steam and now they released the remastered version ( 1 year ago ) and it's absolutely fantastic.
Better graphics and a faster engine makes this game run even more fluently and bug-free, in a nutshell a very polished and well made word game.
In this game you get a bunch of letters and it's your job to make as much words of it to defeat enemies and boss enemies, how further you progress how more game conditions you have to follow up ( like time and poisoned letters ).

There are alot of different tiles/letters which each have their own special effect which influences the entire gameplay, it gets challenging as hell on high levels.
If you are done with the game because you completed it than there is a new endless mode aswell.Pros:
- Alot of different tiles to discover: Like i said; there are alot of different tiles with each it's own effect like tiles that burn and poisoned tiles that deals damage to you instead of the enemy
- Innovative gameplay: Alot of ingame elements are not old or used alot and it makes it unique to other word games.
- Sweet music: You'll love the music for sure
- Trading cards support: Express your love with enabling a background or emoticon of this game
- A good bunch of achievements: There are enough achievements to discover
- Controls: Controls are simple and easy
- Performance: Thanks to the unity engine this game is way faster than it's former release
- Graphics: Really cute textures and all graphics got improved in the remastered version[/quote]

I would have liked to have seen some multiplayer option but maybe that could be implented later on.
In a nutshell this game is a cute, fast, cozy and challenging word game for young and old, i can recommend it to every word-gamer-like gamer.

All the best, Cheers <3

reviewText:
It's ok. 5/10

Pros:
1. Decent amount of upgrades

Cons:
1. Gameplay is too simplistic for me. Too casual
2. Very easy.
3. Monsters varied but in an almost meaningless way

I know there are lots of variations to the game. Each level has 5 obtainable stars that amount to at least 5 different playthroughs. Monsters have different abilities or conditions that affect your grid of letters. You can use the gems you obtain throughout the game to buy upgrades or items. But, in the end, it boils down to this - You are spelling words out and that is it. Whether you have a time limit, less letters to choose from, or a strict condition you need to follow, you are always just spelling out words. Just not enough for me to want to play or recommend to others.

I originally got this spell-a-word game on iOS and loved it. The progression was good, the different powers were great, and the look of the game was polished and had a real charm to it. One of my favorite things about it was that the different power-ups could be adapted to certain playstyles instead of just having one set strongest thing. When I saw it was on Steam (and remastered!), I knew I had to pick it up. I was not disappointed. It's just like I remember but better with added stuff. If you like word games, I'd say get it, even though it's $8. It has enough polish to be worth it, I think. If you've played Letter Quest before, I'd still say get it.

Even when playing Scrabble there can be questions about which words are valid, depends on which dictionary and which version of a dictionary you use. Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey is a must have for anyone who likes word puzzles and scrabble like games in general.
I appreciate being able to play one quick 3 minutes game, say for example, try to get a timed star on a level, or play for longer sessions as it does not seem to get boring.
Finding a highly damaging word on a boss stage when your health is low is a rather rewarding experience, something that I have rarely experienced in a word puzzle turn by turn game !
The game adds a lot of variety using special tiles/encounters which has kept it nicely fresh so far (Sure we will all spam QUEEF" or "POOPED" at some point
date: but that's only for uh damage value...)\nI would compare it very favorably against Bookworm adventures

reviewText: This is a funny little game. It is very colourful and fun looking. It is a lovely practice if you are learning English, or if you want to pump-up your vocabulary. It is a nice little stress reliever.

If you like word puzzles, then you will probably enjoy this one.  It plays similar to Bookworm Adventures except that you have a 5 by 3 grid (15 letters) versus Bookworm's 4 by 4 (16 letters).  Certain letters do more damage, but I found that the word length has the dominant effect.  The game throws challenges at you, making you play certain letters, play letters from specified rows, and including tiles with good and bad effects.  Various challenges like playing words that begin with a vowel either as a requirement or for increased damage really changed the way I pieced words together.  What I really like is that this game will give you the definition of the word you wish to play.  Several time, I would stumble onto words I didn't know while trying to form my own and actually learn something.

The main complaint I have with this game concerns the achievements and quests.  Quite a few of these will be attained the longer you play regardless of your skill level.  This kind of makes it pointless.  There are achievements that require
certain types of words like palindromes that are actually interesting.  It is also odd that there is an achievement and quest to play words with no vowels.  Y, and W are considered vowels at times, so I do not think words like SHY, and CWM actually contain no vowels, but that is what the achievement wants.  Mostly I find myself ignoring the achievements and I acquire them as I play the game regardless.

I do enjoy playing this game though.  It is a good, challenging casual word game.
Love this game! The Challenge mode between Dota games is my jam.

Very similar to Popcap's Bookworm Adventure, but with crisp hi-res graphics. Enemies get tougher as you progress through the story mode, but you get to level up your attacks and health as you go. I think the dictionary is probably Australian English, it's not recogised a few UK colloquialisms for me, but seems to have been fine with some words I've picked up from Aussie TV shows. An easy game to pick up and play for 5 or 20 mins, nothing to offend the kids during the daytime and even captures their attention sometimes.

reviewText: Worth every penny and then some for any fan of letter games or achievement junkies. With so many word games out there, it's hard to find one that shines brighter than the rest, but Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey Remasted does so brilliantly.  The visuals are appealing, the music is nostalgic, and the drive to complete your goals is always there.  An Endless" mode is there to satiate your letter crunching once you've completed the meat of the game and does invite additional challenges or competition between friends
date: if you're old enough to remember when high scores mattered.\n\nIt's certainly not without flaw and admittedly
recommended: the last several hours I logged were simply achievement grinding with little emotional investment.  The second half of the quest mode becomes a breeze with the appropriate upgrades
hoursPlayed: but by then you probably don't care because you're working to tick off another achievement.  (Assuming you're as compulsive about that sort of thing as I am.)\n\nOn sale or not
voteText: I highly recommend this game.  If you were interested enough to finish this review
helpfulPercent: it's exceptionally unlikely this game will disappoint you."
